title: F-space
text:
In <a href="functional%20analysis">functional analysis</a>, an F-space is a <a href="vector%20space">vector space</a> formula_1 over the <a href="Real%20number">real</a> or <a href="Complex%20number">complex</a> numbers together with a <a href="Metric%20%28mathematics%29">metric</a> formula_2 such that that 
The operation formula_12is called an F-norm, although in general an F-norm is not required to be homogeneous. By <a href="Translation%20invariance">translation-invariance</a>, the metric is recoverable from the F-norm. Thus, a real or complex F-space is equivalently a real or complex vector space equipped with a complete F-norm.
Some authors use the term rather than , but usually the term "Fréchet space" is reserved for <a href="Locally%20convex%20topological%20vector%20space">locally convex</a> F-spaces. 
Some other authors use the term "F-space" as a synonym of "Fréchet space", by which they mean a locally convex complete metrizable <a href="topological%20vector%20space">topological vector space</a>. 
The metric may or may not necessarily be part of the structure on an F-space; many authors only require that such a space be <a href="Metrizable%20topological%20vector%20space">metrizable</a> in a manner that satisfies the above properties.
Examples.
All <a href="Banach%20space">Banach space</a>s and <a href="Fr%C3%A9chet%20space">Fréchet space</a>s are F-spaces. In particular, a Banach space is an F-space with an additional requirement that formula_13
The <a href="Lp%20space">Lp spaces</a> can be made into F-spaces for all formula_14 and for formula_15 they can be made into locally convex and thus Fréchet spaces and even Banach spaces.
Example 1.
formula_16 is an F-space. It admits no continuous seminorms and no continuous linear functionals — it has trivial <a href="dual%20space">dual space</a>.

Related properties.
The <a href="Open%20mapping%20theorem%20%28functional%20analysis%29">open mapping theorem</a> implies that if formula_29 are topologies on formula_1 that make both formula_31 and formula_32 into <a href="Complete%20topological%20vector%20space">complete</a> <a href="metrizable%20topological%20vector%20space">metrizable topological vector space</a>s (for example, Banach or <a href="Fr%C3%A9chet%20space">Fréchet space</a>s) and if one topology is <a href="Comparison%20of%20topologies">finer or coarser</a> than the other then they must be equal (that is, if formula_33).
